user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMemCmpValue:
```c
bool UtMemCmpValue(const void *Memory, uint8 Value, uint32 Length)
{
    uint32       i;
    const uint8 *Byte_ptr = Memory;

    for (i = 0; i < Length; i++)
    {
        if (Byte_ptr[i] != Value)
        {
            return false;
        }
    }
    return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtMemCmpValue:
typedef uint8_t   uint8
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No unreachable code fragments were found in the provided function. Reasoning: all declarations at function entry are executed. The for loop condition (i < Length) is evaluated at runtime; if Length is zero the loop body is simply not entered and the final 'return true;' is reached (so that return is reachable). If Length > 0 the loop body is reachable and the 'return false;' inside the loop is reachable when a mismatching byte is encountered. There is no code after a guaranteed unconditional return, no mutually exclusive constant conditions, and no constructs that would render any statement unreachable for all possible inputs. Therefore no fragments need further investigation for Rule 2.1 (unreachable code).
